NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
NAEB Box 2002
August 159 1953
University, Alabama
Dr. Harry J. Skornia
ll|. Gregory Hall
University of Illinois
Urbana, Illinois
Dear Harry:
I have finally completed the European trip expense
account which is enclosed. I trust it will be processed
rather quickly inasmuch as I have quite a bit of money out
for travel and more trips coming up in the near future.
The Board had approved up to $300.00 for this trip and
the total, $199.39, is well under that amount. The hotel
and food in connection with the Paris trip are not strictly
a part of the Brussels meeting, but I would have spent as
much or more had I stayed in Brussels for that weekend so I
feel justified in including this. Naturally, I have not
included the difference in transportation which I paid but
have simply listed the round trip fare from London to Brussels
and back to London.
I have listed hotel charges in New York both going and
coming and limousine and taxi charges while in New York and
am taking care of the round trip fare from home to New York
personally. Although I received $1,000.00 from Mr. Fletcher
for the London trip, I am short on actual expenses about
$150.00 above the approximate $100.00 which I spent for gifts
and for personal items. Even though I can ill afford to do
so, I am perfectly willing to lose the $150.00 for the
satisfaction I got from making the trip. The items under
taxis and tips are rather staggering in their total number
although the totals are not high. You know as well as I,
however, the difficulties of traveling by street transporta¬
tion in a foreign city and you are also aware of the cursed
tipping demands involved in European travel.
More details on other business later.
My kindest regards.
GA/jeh
Sineerely,

President, NAEB
